X. alfalfae subsp. alfalfae is pathogenic on the legume model, Medicago truncatula. Lesions first appear on leaf as water-soaked spots surrounded by diffusible chlorotic area, then dry, turn yellow-brown and become papery. Severe defoliation is a common result of leaf infection. Post-emergence damping off, stunting of seedlings and also damage of lucerne stands are other symptoms. This seed-borne disease may cause severe losses in hot, moist environments, but losses are generally minor. Having access to Xaa genome will allow a better knowledge of the mechanisms involved in the interactions between a legume and a seed-borne foliar pathogen."						3086.0x		65	1	2	Yes	Natural					5/6/14	8/9/13														Erick	none	none	none	Bacteria	Proteobacteria	Gp0045406	Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. glycines CFBP 2526		52369	Gi0052369	Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. glycines CFBP 2526	212247	PRJNA212247	XAGCFBP2526	"Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. glycines, causes a serious disease, bacterial pustule, on soybean that reduces yield and crop quality. This disease occurs during warm and wet weather. The pathogen overwinters in unburied crop residue and can be seed-transmitted. Other hosts, such as snap bean, are recorded. Leaf symptoms include small, pale green spots with elevated pustules, which may develop into large necrotic lesions leading to premature defoliation. Small spots may also develop on pods. Despite high level of resistance in some culivars, the impact of the disease remains high in many parts of the world."						2941.0x		65	1	2	Yes	Natural					5/6/14	8/9/13														Erick	none	none	none	Bacteria	Proteobacteria	Gp0045407	Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. glycines CFBP 7119		52370	Gi0052370	Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. glycines CFBP 7119	212249	PRJNA212249	XAGCFBP7119	"Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. glycines, causes a serious disease, bacterial pustule, on soybean that reduces yield and crop quality. Hubei-1	62195	PRJNA62195	MMB			"This bacterium causes a contagious disease of cattle causing respiratory disease, mastitis, and arthritis. It is found worldwide and is inherently resistant to certain groups of antibiotics because it does not possess a cell wall. More recently, this species has become resistant to tetracycline, tilmicosin and spectinomycin which have been traditionally used in its control. The disease is spread between herds by the transfer of infected but seemingly healthy animals which shed viruses. It has also been introduced into healthy herds via frozen semen collected from an infected bull. The economic losses and negative impact on international trade from this disease have been considerable, and efforts are now underway to develop a vaccine."						29	1	0	Yes	Natural					4/8/14	1/27/11														Erick	Host	Mammals	none	Bacteria	Tenericutes	Gp0006916	Mycoplasma bovoculi M165/69		16869	Gc0016869	Mycoplasma bovoculi M165/69	46455	PRJNA46455	MYB			Mycoplasma bovoculi M165/69 Genome sequencing						28	1	0	Yes	Natural					4/8/14	3/10/10														Erick	Host	none	none	Bacteria	Tenericutes	Gp0091479	Mycoplasma californicum ST-6		72555	Gc0072555	Mycoplasma californicum	242382	PRJNA242382	MCFN			"Genome sequencing of Mycoplasma californicum str. reservoir	Bacteria	Thermotogae	Gp0023644	Thermotoga hypogea NBRC 106472		28911	Gc0028911	Thermotoga hypogea NBRC 106472	172331	PRJDB362	THY01S		"A new thermophilic, xylanolytic, strictly anaerobic, rod-shaped bacterium, strain SEBR 7054T, was isolated from an African oil-producing well. Based on the presence of an outer sheath (toga) and 16S rRNA sequence analysis data, this organism was identified as a member of the genus Thermotoga. Strain SEBR 7054T possessed lateral flagella, had a G + C content of 50 mol%, produced traces of ethanol from glucose but no lactate, and grew optimally in the presence of 0 to 0.2% NaCl at 70 degrees C. Its phenotypic and phylogenetic characteristics clearly differed from those reported for the five previously validly described Thermotoga species. Therefore, we propose that strain SEBR 7054T is a member of a new species of the genus Thermotoga, Thermotoga hypogea sp. nov. The type strain of T. hypogea is SEBR 7054 (= DSM 11164)." rouxii CBS 732		12618	Gc01046	Zygosaccharomyces rouxii CBS 732	12502	PRJNA12502				"ygosaccharomyces rouxii, formerly known as Saccharomyces rouxii, is a homothallic diploid yeast. It is salt-tolerant and osmotolerant, features that allow this organism to cause spoilage of foods such as fruit juices, jams, salad dressings, and bakery products. Zygosaccharomyces rouxii is used in the fermentation processes of some salted Asian foods, such as soy sauce. It is able to depolymerize tannin extracts. The Zygosaccharomyces rouxii genome is approximately 9.8 Mb, organized in 7 chromosomes."		random genomic DNA library containing 3- to 5-kb inserts		11.1x		39	7	0	Yes	Natural					11/13/12	11/27/07												soil as in gold	1	Erick	Soil	Solid waste	Composting	Eukaryota	Ascomycota	Gp0004720	Myceliophthora thermophila ATCC 42464	Myceliophthora thermophila (formerly Sporotrichum thermophile ATCC 42464)	14144	Gc0014144	Myceliophthora thermophila ATCC 42464	32775	PRJNA32775	MYCTH			Myceliophthora thermophila ATCC 42464 Genome sequencing						51	7	0	Yes	Natural			52010	52146	5/1/14	11/29/08													1	Erick	Host-Soil	none	none	Eukaryota	Basidiomycota	Gp0000508	Cryptococcus neoformans var neoformans JEC 21		10438	Gc00247	Cryptococcus neoformans var. neoformans JEC21	13856	PRJNA13856	CN			WGS sequencing of strain JEC21 (serotype D)		"2-3 kb, 3-4 kb, 8-12 kb, 25-40 kb"		12.5x		49	14	0	Yes	Natural					2/7/11	11/27/07
